approach: Database abstraction allowing users to choose storage backend

overview.concept: Provider pattern that decouples app logic from storage implementation
overview.userBenefit: Users choose where their data lives (cloud, local, sheets, etc.)

architecture.diagram: App ‚Üí Storage Interface ‚Üí [Supabase | Sheets | SQLite | Firebase | Custom]

layers.application: React Native app components and screens
layers.storage: Actual storage backend (PostgreSQL, Google Sheets, SQLite, etc.)

storageInterface.purpose: Defines common contract all storage providers must implement

configuration.setup: User provides Supabase project credentials in settings

googleSheets.description: Stores notes as rows in Google Sheets spreadsheet

configuration.setup: User authenticates with Google, app creates/uses spreadsheet

cons: No multi-device sync (unless paired with cloud)

configuration.optional: Can configure cloud backup for sync

configuration.setup: User creates Firebase project, adds credentials

notion.description: Store notes as Notion pages in a database
notion.implementation: Uses Notion API to create/update pages
notion.benefit: Users can access notes in Notion + your app

airtable.benefit: Users can use Airtable's powerful features (views, formulas)

dropbox.description: Store notes as markdown files in Dropbox

customAPI.description: User provides their own API endpoint

providerFactory.purpose: Creates provider instances based on type

storageContext.purpose: React Context to provide storage provider throughout app

settingsUI.purpose: Allow users to select and configure storage provider

sheets.flow:
1. User signs in with Google
2. App creates spreadsheet or user provides ID
3. App sets up sheet structure (columns)
4. Provider switches to Sheets

firebase.flow:
1. User creates Firebase project
2. User copies credentials
3. App validates credentials
4. Provider switches to Firebase

custom.flow:
1. User provides API endpoint
2. App tests connection
3. User configures auth
4. Provider switches to custom API

dataMigration.purpose: Allow users to move notes between providers

phase1.name: Foundation
tasks: Update existing code to use abstraction
phase1.deliverable: App works with Supabase OR SQLite (user choice)

phase2.name: Expansion
tasks: Add provider selection UI in settings
phase2.deliverable: Users can choose between Supabase, SQLite, or Google Sheets

phase3.name: Advanced
tasks: Add data migration tools (move between providers)
Add sync feature (local SQLite + cloud backup)
phase3.deliverable: Full multi-provider support with migration tools

futurePhases.selfHosted: Allow users to run their own backend

bringYourOwn.concept: Users can use their own Supabase/Firebase/etc. accounts
bringYourOwn.benefit: No ongoing costs for you, user has full control
bringYourOwn.revenue: One-time purchase or subscription for advanced features

testing.integration: Test each provider implementation with real backends

obsidian.approach: Local files + optional sync providers (Obsidian Sync, iCloud, Dropbox)
obsidian.lesson: Users love local-first with optional cloud sync

logseq.lesson: Open architecture builds trust and community

standardNotes.lesson: Privacy-focused users will pay for control

joplin.approach: Sync to Dropbox, OneDrive, Nextcloud, WebDAV, etc.
